title: How To Train Your Dog Not To Chew On Household Items
summary: There are a few mistakes that dogs owners often make when trying to train their dogs not to chew. Before you start training your dog, make sure you avoid these mistakes. Don’t punish your dog for chewing – it’s how they learn and explore their world. Use a word or phrase to let your dog know the item he is chewing on is off-limits. Train your dog outdoors and let him know that he can only chew on his toys on the grass. Teach your dog the “Off” command to “off” items that you absolutely don't want your dog to chew on, but you might even be tempted to.

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:o,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:o,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Are you ready to give up chewing on household objects? How about your dog? Dogs love to chew. It\u2019s something that comes naturally for them, and there are many things you can buy or make that will help satisfy their natural instincts to chew. But as much as dogs love to have objects that they can gnaw on, it\u2019s not always safe \u2013 or advisable \u2013 to let them do it in the home. There are plenty of household items that dogs shouldn\u2019t be allowed to chew, because it could lead to potential hazards or unsanitary conditions.
Even if your dog has never chewed on inappropriate things before, a new puppy will almost certainly try out things beyond what is safe for him. How you train him from the very beginning will determine how much damage he can do if he goes after something he shouldn\u2019t. So read on and learn how to stop your dog from chewing on anything other than his own toys.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

Dogs naturally keep their dens clean, so they don\u2019t like to have dirt and other things inside. Dogs are also very observant of their surroundings, so he will notice that grass doesn\u2019t make its way inside his mouth."),mdx("h2",null,"Teach Your Dog The \u201COff\u201D Command"),mdx("p",null,"If there are items that you absolutely don\u2019t want your dog to chew on, you can teach him to \u201Coff\u201D those items. This is helpful for items that your dog might even be tempted to chew on, but you don\u2019t want him to. This can be something like a table leg or a curtain. Start by having your dog on a leash and having him near the item you want him to ignore. When he starts to chew on it, give him a short yelp and then pull him away from the item. Then reward him for not chewing on it. Your dog won\u2019t be able to get a grip on the item and will lose interest in chewing on it."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"You can also make the items taste bad with hot sauce or cayenne pepper.")),mdx("h2",null,"Put Together A Reward Program"),mdx("p",null,"Rewards aren\u2019t just for humans. Training your dog to stop chewing on the things he shouldn\u2019t be chewing on should be a reward-based process. You want to make sure that your dog knows that he\u2019s doing the right thing. Make sure you have plenty of healthy treats on hand so you can reward your dog for making the right choices. If you want to use things that aren\u2019t food-based, make sure they\u2019re safe for your dog. Keep in mind that you want to reward your dog for making the right choices, not just chewing on his own toys. He\u2019ll need to know that it\u2019s OK for him to chew on his toys, but not on the things in your house that he doesn\u2019t belong chewing on."),mdx("h2",null,"Conclusion"),mdx("p",null,"Dogs love to chew, but they don\u2019t always love chewing on their own toys. As much as you want your dog to enjoy his toys, you also want to make sure he\u2019s chewing on things that are safe for him and your home. To train your dog to stop chewing on household items, you need to start early and be consistent with your training. Be patient with your dog, and don\u2019t be too hard on yourself if it takes a little time for him to learn what he\u2019s supposed to do. relatedArticles.title: How the Pandemic Is Changing the Way We Work

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...n}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...n,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Time is money, as the saying goes. And when you\u2019re grappling with pandemic disease and a global outbreak, time spent at work has a whole different set of implications.
Pandemic flu strains have decimated human populations since the first recorded pandemic in 541 AD. Over the centuries, outbreaks have been frequent enough to instill fear in even the most stoic among us.
Today we face another pandemic threat with the potential to be even more devastating than those which came before it. A highly virulent strain of influenza A virus known as influenza pandemia has begun spreading rapidly throughout much of the world.
In many ways, today\u2019s workplace is very different from that of a century ago. Technology has advanced; office structures are more open and collaborative; and workers are expected to demonstrate self-motivation and flexibility in order to thrive in an ever-changing workplace environment.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 5 Tips for Eating Healthy on a Budget

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Are you trying to eat healthier but find that healthy foods are expensive? Are you trying to make a good meal last for several days and not just one? Are you struggling to find affordable, healthy options near your home or work? If so, you\u2019re not alone. Eating healthy can be expensive and challenging. The cost of healthy food has gone up while the cost of unhealthy food has gone down. But this doesn\u2019t mean that eating healthy is impossible; it just means we all need to get a little bit more creative.
Eating well on a budget can be challenging, but it isn\u2019t impossible. Making smart choices about what you buy as well as how you cook your food can make a big difference in how much money you spend on food each month and how healthy your diet is at the same time.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Train Your Dog to Drop It
How to Train Your Dog to Come When Called

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Do you have a well-trained dog? If not, are you looking for a way to improve? Coming when called is an essential command that most pet owners neglect. When your dog comes when called, it means he will come back to you right away and not run away or chase something else. This will help keep your dog safe, especially if he\u2019s prone to running away or chasing objects or other animals. It also helps with training and makes everyday interactions much easier than having to constantly chase after your pet.
But perhaps the most important reason why you should train your dog to come when called is because it might just save his life one day. In many cases, dogs that run away don\u2019t get lost, they are just trying to find a way back home. Therefore, knowing how to train your dog to come when called can be the difference between him coming home safe and sound or getting lost forever. And let\u2019s face it \u2013 nobody wants that!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Train Your Dog to Walk on a Leash
How to Deal with a Partner Who's Always Working

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Working too much is a problem many people struggle with \u2014 but it\u2019s even more challenging when you\u2019re in a relationship with someone who has the same work ethic. If your partner usually leaves for work before you even get out of bed, or isn\u2019t home until after you\u2019re already in bed, things can get tricky.
Working from home, flexible hours and remote working are all buzzwords in today\u2019s labor market. Companies are becoming increasingly aware that it isn\u2019t just about how much time employees spend at the desk but also about what they achieve during that time. A Gallup poll found that telecommuting or working from home is growing in popularity among professionals across most industries. Working remotely makes it easier to find jobs, negotiate schedules and live without a commute.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Deal with Envy in Relationships

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Being in a new relationship is exciting and often feels like a whirlwind. You spend time getting to know each other and spending time together as much as possible. But things can change once you enter a committed relationship or get married. Stressors from work, family, friends and other responsibilities may arise, putting stress on your relationship. This is when green-eyed monster envy creeps in and can have a negative impact on your partner.
There are many different types of relationships: friendships, casual dating or serious partners. Regardless of what type of relationships you have with another person, envy probably won\u2019t be far behind if they are important to you. Envy is one of the seven deadly sins for good reason. When we experience envy in a relationship it creates distrust, resentment and can ultimately end things prematurely before they even really begin. However, there are ways to deal with this feeling so that it doesn\u2019t get the better of you.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 50 Ways to Keep the Spark Alive in Your Relationship
How to Get Out of a Style Rut

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"The risk of falling into a style rut is something we all have to deal with from time to time. It happens to even the most confident and daring of people, so you\u2019re certainly not alone if you feel like your style is stagnating and you can\u2019t think of anything new or exciting to wear. Whether it\u2019s because you haven\u2019t found a new piece of clothing that excites you in months, or because you just don\u2019t know what to wear after wearing variations on the same theme for several weeks in a row, everyone gets stuck in a rut now and again. Thankfully there are ways to get out of it and discover a new lease on your personal style once again."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
